The Treatise says:
If the perfect mirror cognition can produce the images of knowledge, then it must be the case that it is of the same size as they are and can be found.
In order to explain this difficulty, the text says that it is like a great image that can be found in a perfect mirror, that is, the images of the great earth, etc.

Mirror wisdom is also like this. Although it gives rise to images of the wisdoms of the various stages, mundane and supramundane, because they are formless, it is not the same as those images in size. For this reason, the mirror wisdom of buddhas is called the great treasury of wisdom, because it is the root of the wisdoms of the world and of those who transcend the world. The treatise says:
There are three kinds of compassion:
First, compassion that takes sentient beings as its object;
Second, compassion that takes the Dharma as its object;
Third, compassion that takes the absence of characteristics as its object.

Bodhisattvas in the stage of initial aspiration mainly cultivate compassion that takes sentient beings as its object. This is mostly contaminated, because it takes conventional existence as its object.

Bodhisattvas in the stage of correct practice cultivate the compassion that has dharmas as its object to a great degree, but it is also greatly contaminated, because the teachings of the Great Vehicle are its object.

Bodhisattvas who have attained the tolerance of the non-arising of dharmas cultivate the compassion that has no object to a great degree. Even though it has an object, it takes the dharma realm as its object.

It is like the various dharmas that are the results of retribution of the eye, etc., which are devoid of discrimination and evolve spontaneously without any effort, and for that reason it is called the great compassion associated with the knowledge of sameness.

According to another interpretation, it has only the dharma realm as its object, because the discrimination of objects is forever absent. It does not take sentient beings or dharmas as objects and for that reason it is called compassion that has no object.
According to yet another interpretation, it also takes dharmas as objects.

According to the correct interpretation, it also takes sentient beings as objects, but it is devoid of discrimination. Its mode of activity is that of sameness, because it understands that all sentient beings are equally established, that the nature of dharmas such as birth are the same, and that the suchness of nonself is the same. It is called the knowledge of sameness.

Because it is superior to that of all the disciples and solitary enlightened ones, because it saves all sentient beings, and because it is fully accomplished by the accumulation of the provisions of merit and knowledge over a long period of time, it is called extensive salvation.
